> Hi Jeff,
> 
> Thanks for your interest in our paper.

Hi David. No problem. Thanks for the answers.

> In response to comments 1-3, we've actually run several preliminary
> experiments with the intent of answering the questions you've asked.  We hope
> to have a publication with formal results based on those experiments soon.  In
> general though, we do feel that this approach is superior to the one discussed
> in the previous multiagent HyperNEAT paper and would recommend anyone who
> wants to work with multiagent HyperNEAT to use the z-based substrate.

Cool. I look forward to seeing the paper.

> 4.  Way back when I first converted SharpNEAT to HyperSharpNEAT I tried a
> number of values and found that there wasn't a large difference between them,
> although 20% seemed to be slightly better.  For any new domains I'll try a few
> values to see if they make any difference, but I haven't found any where the
> elitism value made a significant difference.
> 
> I will say that I've never tried just saving the best organism.  One reason is
> that the SharpNEAT speciation code isn't really designed to only save one
> genome.  The other is that I think saving at least the best genomes in your
> best species would help prevent promising species from accidentally dying off
> too early.  On the other hand, I know you have several successful HyperNEAT
> experiments, so I guess I'll turn the question back on you: Have you found
> saving just the best genome to generally be better than saving more?  I'm
> certainly willing to give it a try if you've seen much better results.

I have never changed these parameters. But now that we are discussing it I
am realizing I don't actually know how much elitism I am using. I think I am
using the same parameters from Jason's experiments. I was focusing on this
parameter, which is why I said I keep only the best org:

ForceCopyGenerationChampion 1.0

But I now also see these parameters in my experiment config files:

SmallestSpeciesSizeWithElitism 5.0
MutateSpeciesChampionProbability 0.0

How do I figure out my % elitism, so I know how my number compares to your
20%?  

> 5.  The answer to whether we renormalize the sheets or insert the new sheets
> between the old is technically both.  In general we renormalize, that is
> however many agents there are, they are evenly spaced between -1 and 1.  While
> it may seem like a good idea to leave the original sheets where they were and
> insert the new ones among them, in most cases it is difficult to determine
> where the new sheets should go.
> 
> For example, if there were 5 agents located at z={-1, -0.5, 0, 0.5, 1} and the
> team needed to be scaled to 7 agents, where should the two new agents go?
> There are two agents, but four spaces (-0.75, -0.25, 0.25, 0.75) to put them
> and no real reason to choose any of the spaces over the others.  By
> redistributing the agents evenly we eliminate such ad hoc decisions.  However,
> if the 5 agent team were to be scaled up to 9 agents, they would be placed at
> z={-1, -0.75, -0.5, -0.25, 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75,1}.  Thus, even though we're
> renormalizing, the placement works out the same as if we had inserted the new
> agents among the old.

That makes sense, and seems like the right way to do it.

> 6.  The sign function simply returns the sign of the node's activation: -1 if
> the activation is negative, 0 if it is 0, and 1 if it is positive.
>The reason 
> for this function and the starting structure is to establish a team with
> mirror symmetry i.e. the ANN of the agent at z= 1 is the horizontally flipped
> version of the agent at z=-1 and so on.  We found that team mirror symmetry
> was beneficial in both domains that were tested in this paper, so it was
> logical to allow it to start with symmetry (which can be broken or ignored
> with mutations).

Ok. I get it. Thanks for clarifying.

> I hope I've answered your questions,

You did. Thanks again for all the answers, and congrats on the great work.

-Jeff

> David
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Congrats on this paper. It features a lot of nice results.
>> 
>> A few questions/comments:
>> 
>> 1) The issue of interpolation is extremely interesting. In this paper you
>> explicitly discuss how it would be beneficial to add new agents, and have
>> their roles be intermediate versions of other agents (e.g., adding a 12th
>> soccer player between the forwards and the midfielders would create a player
>> that was a hybrid of the two roles). It would also be cool to see if teams
>> can gracefully re-divide the strategy-space when they lose agents. For
>> example, in soccer/futbol, after a few red cards are assigned, each player
>> does not play the usual role that they would play on a team of 11, but
>> instead re-divide the space up amongst the fewer players. For example, after
>> the red cards their may be a left and right forward instead of a left, right
>> and center forward. It would be cool to see if you can see such a result
>> using your method.
>> 
>> 2) You mention the benefits of interpolated roles, but do you have any
>> evidence that such interpolation is occurring? One cool way to test this
>> would be to compare two different treatments: T1) take your original N
>> agents and multiply them to achieve the desired scaled-up number of agents
>> (e.g., 9, 25, 100, 1000). If you start with 10 agents, and scale to 1000,
>> you thus get 100 identical copies of agent 1, 100 identical copies of agent
>> 2, etc. Compare the performance of this treatment to T2) interpolate 1000
>> agents into the z coordinate range, so you have 1000 slightly different
>> agents. The difference in performance between these treatments will help you
>> figure out whether you are seeing a boost due to interpolation. If the
>> performance increase due to scaling is not different between T1 and T2, then
>> you know your performance boost was simply due to having more agents, not
>> due to interpolation (you note something similar when you say "adding more
>> agents that all do the same thing will eventually cause a pile-up"...my
>> suggestion is a way to test this claim).
>> 
>> 3) Why do you feel this new technique is better than your old technique? Is
>> it possible to compare the two experimentally? Have you done so?
>> 
>> 4) I notice you mention that you use 20% elitism. I usually only save the
>> best organism. Have you found 20% to work a lot better, generally?
>> 
>> 5) When you add new agents, do you leave the previous sheets in the same
>> place, and interpolate new sheets between them, or do you renormalize all of
>> the sheets such that it may be the case that no new agent is in the exact z
>> coordinate of one of the original agents? It might be interesting to try
>> both and see which tends to work better.
>> 
>> 6) What is the 'sign' function you mention in Figure 2? In general, I am
>> having trouble figuring out what this means: "The starting structure of the
>> initial heterogeneous CPPN (Figure 2b) includes some additional structure to
>> start evolution with knowledge of mirrored team symmetry; in particular, the
>> sign function of z connected to multiplication operators on the x-axis means
>> that the CPPN knows which side of the team is which and can opt to reflect
>> one side across the midline."
>> 
>> Congrats again on this nice work.
>> 
>> Best regards,
>> Jeff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>> jclune@...
>> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>>> From: Ken <kstanley@...>
>>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Date: Thu, 28 Jan 2010 02:59:22 -0000
>>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Subject: [neat] Multiagent HyperNEAT Revisited
>>> 
>>> Our 2008 GECCO paper by David D'Ambrosio and myself introduced the idea that
>>> a
>>> single HyperNEAT CPPN can encode a set of neural networks (instead of just
>>> one) that represent a pattern of policies for an entire team.  Since then a
>>> few people have asked about the way we laid out the team on the substrate
>>> and
>>> whether alternatives might be better.
>>> 
>>> I am happy to announce, with my co-authors David D'Ambrosio, Joel Lehman,
>>> and
>>> Sebastian Risi, that we have extensively tested such an alternative
>>> z-axis-based encoding and published the results to appear in AAMAS 2010,
>>> available here:
>>> 
>>> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html
>>> 
>>> Direct Link: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_aamas10.pdf
>>> 
>>> We believe this z-based substrate layout is superior to the previous one,
>>> particularly for scaling the size of the team, and should open up the field
>>> of
>>> multiagent learning further to HyperNEAT.  The paper also includes the first
>>> published results on scaling the size of the team without further training,
>>> which works because HyperNEAT can interpolate new policies for ANNs inserted
>>> along the z axis of the substrate.
>>> 
>>> Videos that accompany the paper are here:
>>> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/mahnaamas2010.html
>>> 
>>> ken
>>> 
>> 
>
